utterances: I knew you were going to ask that.

Amy is part of our regular ""Ask Amy"" segment - our show's not over.
We're talking with Amy Dickinson, the author of the ""Ask Amy,"" syndicated columnist for the Chicago Tribune.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
We were doing nightmares earlier - getting the clock wrong.

This is Carlos(ph), Carlos with us from San Francisco.
Hello.
Hi, Carlos.
You're on the air.
Yes.
Hi.
I just want to relate an incident that happened about four years ago.
I had a bunch of teenagers come to the door and in were kids between 14 and 16.
It was at the end of the night, and I gave them about four or five pieces of candy.
And they said this is not enough.
I only said, when I said, well, that's all I have, you know?
It's the end of the night.
And I closed the door, and then like 20 seconds later, bang, the window on the second floor is broken with a stone.
With a stone.
Yes.
And then, I called the cops, and the cops came with well pressed uniforms and a shiny car and they said - they started laughing and - no, you don't have insurance, do you?
And there was the end of that.
So…
Boys will be boys.
It's Halloween.
Forget about it.
Well, tomorrow, I'm going to the opera.
And in the last three years or four years, so we had it a goal visiting friends who are not Halloween, you know, aficionados or we go to a show, or we go to out to dinner.
And I should say one more thing, that, you know, I have a great dislike for columnists who set the rules for the rest of humanity.
Well, then I'm so glad you called.
Thank you, Carlos.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
You know, just another fan, Neal.
But you know what?
He makes a great point that is really, really frightening, horrifying.
And I don't blame him or his family for choosing not to participate.
Honestly, that's awful.

And should the rule be that - I know you hesitate to make rules for the rest of us, Amy - but should the rule be that if there's no jack-o'-lantern or decoration on a door, hey, go down to the next door.
Yeah.
I mean the, you know, I think the universal rule is if the porch light is off, you move along.
And there's no excuse for vandalism, obviously ever.
But you did say Halloween, the trick part, kind of the thrill is that things can get a little out of control.
Well, I do like the feeling.

I certainly liked it as a kid, that idea that you were never quite sure what was going to happen and actually, I think that's one of the good things about Halloween for children is that it's actually a good thing to be a little bit scared.
And I - in the previous segment on nightmares, you were talking about it, and I really see Halloween as an opportunity for kids to kind of process some of their fears.
Unfortunately, the more we commercialize it and snatch it from kids, the less able they're going to be able to do that.
Mm-hmm.
